Martha and Cathrine are for the die-hard's because once you get to Mary's its hard to leave it but please do yourself a favor and press on, its worth it.
For a easier way to see the sisters, go up Little Cottonwood Canyon, go to Albien Basin and you'll find Cathrine pass... going downhill the whole time makes it easier for the younger or inexperienced ones. Bring lots of water or a filter for the lakes. Its a water shed area, leave the dogs at home.

reviews.name: French S
reviews.title: One beautiful drive
reviews.comment: We love to drive thru Big Cottonwood Canyon going back to Deer Valley. Gorgeous views of the canyon and wildlife sightings are a plus.

reviews.name: BKSNtravel
reviews.title: Beautiful in the summer and great hiking
reviews.comment: The canyon drive is breathtaking. Watch out for many sports enthusiasts - lots of bikers and runners. We hiked two trails. Dog Lake was a peaceful hike with amazing wildflowers. When we were about .5 miles from the lake the misquotes were all over us. Bring bug spray for this hike. Also the last .5 miles is a steep climb. We also hiked Willow Heights. Perfect hike with young kids. There are ducks at the lake. We were the only people at the lake it was incredible peaceful.

reviews.name: Sekou R
reviews.title: Breathtaking
reviews.comment: If you have the time make it up Big Cottonwood. I took a morning and drove up there solo. The granite cliffs, lush greenery, and cascading streams made it all worth it. Take your time going up, there are a lot of twists and turns. What a view!!

reviews.name: NoelsCat
reviews.title: Trip advisors address listing is wrong… GPS warning
reviews.comment: This is actually a beautiful place --- when we ended up getting there. One word of caution: DO NOT USE THE ADDRESS LISTED IN THIS TRIP ADVISOR (3872 S. Swallow) as it is wrong. Unfortunately, I did and spent over an hour and a half driving around in the heat.

reviews.name: Letsgosomewherecool
reviews.title: Scenic Drive, Great Hikes
reviews.comment: We took the drive through Cottonwood Canyon from the Salt Lake Airport on the way to my cousin's house in Midway (on the other side of the mountains). It is a truly beautiful drive, with lovely views all around. There are also plenty of trails along the road -- my husband and I just stopped at a few, and walked to Doughnut Falls and some of Mill B. I think you could either plan out where you want to hike, or do kind of like we did and just stop when you feel like it! We also took Guardsman Pass to Midway -- it's a tricky curvy drive up the mountain, closed in the winter, but when we were there in July it was really beautiful. We are really glad we took the "long way" through Cottonwood Canyon to my cousin's house instead of taking the interstate -- we enjoyed the drive and the hikes!

reviews.name: Candy R
reviews.title: Big Cottonwood Canyon
reviews.comment: Nice scenery, treacherous roads that have curves not protected by guardrails. Not advisable trip during the winter months, unless you have snow chains available. BCC is loaded with ski resorts that are amazing both summer and winter. Free snow lift rides in the winter months. Park rangers are OK, but those we've been around are not helpful, not friendly as the locals seem to be. Plenty of picnic spaces, hiking trails and ampi-theaters available throughout the canyon.

reviews.name: ruup4adventure2
reviews.title: Perfect for picnics
reviews.comment: Big Cottonwood is a great canyon for a leisurely afternoon drive or picnic. There are numerous picnic tables along the route. At the top of the canyon, you can enjoy an easy walk around Silver Lake or stop in at the visitor center for more information on local plants and wildlife. This canyon is linked to Heber and Park City via Guardsmans Pass at the top of the canyon (just before Brighton). Guardman's isn't paved the whole way, but it's good enough to take a sedan. Note: dogs are not allowed in this canyon as it is a watershed area.

reviews.name: mmaurycy
reviews.title: A great place to hike and generally recreate.
reviews.comment: Big Cottonwood Canyon has lots of great hikes for all different levels of hikers. Donut Falls is a lovely easy hike and for more moderate ones Dog Lake with a detour to Desolation Lake is also wonderful. Up the highway you also find Silver Lake just beyond Solitude Ski Resort and numerous easy hikes at Brighton Resort. The Lake Mary and Lake Catherine's hikes are a definite must. Be aware that you may see moose on these hikes. A great area to enjoy family recreation. Both Brighton and Solitude are also wonderful places to ski and snowboard during the snow months. Enjoy!

reviews.name: Paulette W
reviews.title: Snowbird Lodge
reviews.comment:
Beautiful scenery. Many summer activities at the lodge and near by.
Higher elevation was challenging for breathing.

reviews.name: kkline4970
reviews.title: Silver Lake walk
reviews.comment: We took a few laps around Silver Lake on a calm Sunday afternoon. Plenty of visitors, but there is plenty of trail for everyone. We popped over to the little store for a beverage after, relaxed in the sun at the green tables out on the patio. Several people were ordering hamburgers. Great family atmosphere.

reviews.name: Virginia O
reviews.title: Lovely drive in mid-May, but Suggest Going in Summer
reviews.comment: Nice places to picnic by a babbling stream along the route to Solitude & Brighton ski resorts. There was still snow above 7,000 ft. The Guardman Pass was closed until around the beginning of June, as it's around 10,000 ft. Hence, there was no way to get through to Park City from here in May. A popular place for the locals for a Sunday drive. Lovely scenery, but many trees at the higher elevations are not in leaf yet. It must be an even better drive from June & throughout the summer. The canyon walls coming down from the ski areas are extremely picturesque when the sun is on them.

reviews.name: JDBuchanan
reviews.title: Awe-inspiring beauty!
reviews.comment: Don't miss the cottonwood canyons. For a drive, hiking, camping, climbing, or adventure sports, I've experience few places with the sheer awe-inspiring beauty and cool vibe of this region of Utah. For the daredevil, try driving the guardmen's pass between Park City and the canyon/Salt Lake City. It's incredible. I find that I'm being drawn back for more, and I can't wait to visit again.

reviews.name: Keytothekingdom
reviews.title: best free outing in Utah
reviews.comment:
Great place to escape the Utah summer heat.
Bring a picnic and stay all day (picnic sites require a small fee.) Best of all they have real bathrooms. No dogs allowed in the canyon to protect the valleys drinking water which comes from the river in the canyon.

reviews.name: John N
reviews.title: Climber's paradise
reviews.comment: There are multiple sites with easy access. Full range from five easy to five hard. Lucky people in SLC!

reviews.name: drgoodhands
reviews.title: Great hikes, local views
reviews.comment: It was a nice drive into Cottonwood Canyon and an even better drive from the canyon to Park City. We parked at the Brighton ski area with several hike choices. Nice hike up to Twin Lakes reservoir.

reviews.name: DonSpencer
reviews.title: Peaceful Mtn. Drive
reviews.comment: Looking to get away then this is a quick drive up a beautiful canyon any time of the year! Take snacks or stop at one of the local pubs at the bottom of the canyon or at the top. Dress accordingly to the weather.

reviews.name: teek4100
reviews.title: Go for a drive, perhaps a hike and be inspired
reviews.comment: The fact that you have such beauty just 30 minutes from downtown Salt Lake City is quite special. Enjoy a great drive up one of the Valleys Canyons. Map it out first and drive over Guardsman Pass and you are dropped off into the Deer Valley / Park City area.

reviews.name: Cswee1967
reviews.title: Nice hike
reviews.comment: Had a nice hike to Donut Falls but be careful on the last 50 yards uphill to the falls, especially when the snow is melting. Hike is very easy and can be done by all ages until the very end.

reviews.name: Karen O
reviews.title: Fun and beautiful
reviews.comment: The only bad thing about cottonwood canyon is that is a water shed and you cannot take your dogs. Otherwise, there are many beautiful places to hike and plenty of picture opportunities.

reviews.name: bobo231
reviews.title: Awesome Drive - Varies by Season
reviews.comment:
I have been doing this drive for many years, in the winter, to access Solitude and Brighton Ski Areas. I suggest picking good weather ... this drive is harrowing during a snowstorm. Also, take along a geologist to explain the fabulous and varied rock formations. Be prepared for hairpin turns, a beautiful stream (be careful not to polute anything in the pristine canyons).
Look out for rock climbers ... tiny dots on the granite faces. There are places to hike and cross country ski. Solitude is one of my favorite ski areas when the snow is fresh and the sun shines ... otherwise not that great. Brighton is great on a snowy day because there are many trails through the trees. Both have good lunch menus in season. Enjoy1

reviews.name: Motrzo
reviews.title: breath taking
reviews.comment: Although I don't want this beautiful canyon to be overrun - it is not to be missed. It is worth the drive.

reviews.name: gardengirl01966
reviews.title: Hiking in the snow in May
reviews.comment: Went to hike and my trail original was closed due to snow.We did doughnut Falls instead. It had some snow and ice too, but was passable. Beautiful hike,we really enjoyed the scenic drive too.

reviews.name: Brian A
reviews.title: great hikes
reviews.comment: Get a good map guide and try some hikes that take you to ridge line so you can see into adjacent valleys. Most of these start up near Guardsman Pass. The views are absolutely stunning. The trails can get busy on weekends. There are some beautiful lakes - some of the best hiking photos I've taken. Take plenty of fluid and wear sunscreen, as with any hike in this region. It is amazing how close this fantastic valley is to the city. Take advantage of it!

reviews.name: barbieutah
reviews.title: All year 'round to visit
reviews.comment: Beautiful canyon year round. Great to go up to ski, to bike, hike. Go over the Guardsman pass for a spectacular view of Midway and drive over to either go to Park City/Deer Valley or to Midway and Heber. Great fall color drive. Don't miss Silver Fork Inn for a delicious meal especially in good weather with the deck and the view and the hummingbirds.

reviews.name: Madison K
reviews.title: Absolute beauty!
reviews.comment: I love driving through Big Cottonwood Canyon every summer and fall. It's the best scenic drive in Utah.

reviews.name: Sherry B
reviews.title: Lots of snow
reviews.comment: Drove up the canyon 4 times while visiting family. Snowshoed around Silver Lake twice,once while snowing & then on a beautiful day with 14 inches of powder. Watched the kids snowboard another day. Always love the canyon. It's a great place any time of the year. You will need to purchase a snowshoe pass for each person at Silver Lake. $5 per person for the day.

reviews.name: logandiana
reviews.title: We found this place by accident!!
reviews.comment: We asked some family we were visiting about things to do in the area. They told us there was a few hikes up the mountain. We were looking for something called donut falls or something, but we never found it. We drove up the scenic byway to the end of the road and instead found Silver Lake. This is a beautiful alpine lake with an easy boardwalk loop around most of the lake.The lake was clear and while I didn't see any bears or moose, I am sure they were out there. This was another place that was at the top of our list of fun things from our vacation, and to think we almost missed it!! Take your camera and then eat at Silver Fork Lodge Restaurant on your way back down the mountain.

reviews.name: Harris H
reviews.title: Skiing
reviews.comment: One of the best kept secrets in the skiing world. Great snow and no lines. Our favorite in Bighton. Stay at the Brighton Chalets.

reviews.name: bbsteele
reviews.title: My favorite place on earth
reviews.comment: I have always loved Big Cottonwood Canyon. In the winter I love skiing Solitude and Brighton, and in the Summer there are so many beautiful trails to hike. If you are visiting Salt Lake City, do yourself a favor and spend an afternoon in Big Cottonwood.

reviews.name: Patinla
reviews.title: Solitude Mountain Resort
reviews.comment:
We have been coming to Solitude for several years. Why keep coming back?
-On the slopes just 5 hours after leaving home from the bayous of Louisiana. Delta non-stop from New Orleans to SLC- Arrives 10:30am, departs 5:30pm.
Salt Lake City airport to Solitude just 35-40 minutes (rental car or shuttle). Can be skiing with a half-day ticket on first day and can ski right up to the shuttle, pop your skis off, hop in and head to the airport on last day (if you own your own equipment).
-Price of equipment and tickets are very reasonable.
We purchase season tickets off the website in the late summer / early fall. Packages are very good. Our son skis for $25.00/day (lift ticket) as a junior and total rental package is $25.00/day. Husband $49.00/day for lift ticket. Equipment is quality.
-Friendly, knowledgeable, dedicated staff
From the manager of the Solitude’s Snowsports Academy, Leif, to the seasonal workers (ski instructors, rental area, lift operators), we always feel completely welcomed and properly cared for. We have been using the same instructors for years and would highly recommend both, Ron Cook and Helen. Both will up your skiing game every time you ski with them. Ski trips are about skiing. Do not torture yourself. Spend some money on instruction. My son skis double blacks and Ron improves his skills every time and no one knows those dangerous Honeycomb runs like Ron. Worth every penny.
-No lines. No waits for all that beautiful snow.
-Great lodging and helpful, friendly staff.
-Big Cottonwood canyon is seldom closed due to avalanches. Road closures can really ruin your limited vacation time.
-Good, quality food at lodge and at Silver Fork Lodge.
-Snow, snow, snow!!!
The list goes on and on.

reviews.name: redfear
reviews.title: Great views, hiking (walking) and of course - skiing
reviews.comment: Love to drive up Big Cottonwood every season to take in the views. There are numerous places to pull over and walk around or use as a base for a hike.

reviews.name: Kateluvssun
reviews.title: Loved
reviews.comment: No lines. Beautiful. Ticket system worked great. Groomed runs and added snow. Ate at solitude. A grill. Great outdoor dining. Fun day times 100.

reviews.name: AllenMT
reviews.title: worth the drive
reviews.comment: If you have a rental car while visiting SLC, it is worth the drive up Cottonwood Canyon. Stunning views, great little hiking pull-offs. You'll feel as though your climbing up into an alpine meadow by the end.

reviews.name: Moroni S
reviews.title: nice place to hike
reviews.comment: i went there on the morning, and has this great views and the ride is nice, is a great place to visit and exersice, and all the nature around is great, great feeling.

reviews.name: Amy G
reviews.title: Fall colors in Big Cottonwood Canyon
reviews.comment: Fall is beautiful in the mountains and Big Cottonwood Canyon is no exception. We took a hike through pine trees and aspens - it was gorgeous!

reviews.name: BBasche
reviews.title: Beautiful Canyon with plenty to do!
reviews.comment: This canyon is spectacular during every season, Weather you are hiking and dining at Solitude during the summer or catching autumn colors or skiing during the winter!

reviews.name: James B
reviews.title: SnowBird & Alta
reviews.comment: To of the great ski locations in the western US. Former Olympic sites. But this is a year-round place with picnicking, concerts, hiking, backpacking, gondola rides, etc. in the Summer.

reviews.name: Lori K
reviews.title: Breathtaking drive and hikes
reviews.comment: We have lived here since May 2013 and haven't missed a weekend of hiking or a drive through the canyon. Love it! Plenty of hikes of various levels of difficulty, some are even wheelchair accessible. No fees to park or hike. Bathroom and water is available at a few sites.

reviews.name: MiDeCu
reviews.title: Nice view, relaxing....
reviews.comment: As always this place is very nice and relaxing, with family, friend or just by my self I find here pace, nice view and the touching of nature. Hiking, pick nick or just drive and stay for a couple minutes is good.

reviews.name: Fritzy43
reviews.title: So close to the center of the city!
reviews.comment: If you are in SlC and have a rental car (or can tolerate a city bus), spend an hour or two to discover why so many Utahns are into winter sports. When you reach the top of the valley at Brighton, it is hard to believe you are so close to an urban center of 2 million people. These mountains have many beautiful valleys but perhaps none so close to the big hotels of SLC.

reviews.name: Jennifer H
reviews.title: Spectacular scenery!
reviews.comment: This is definitely a place to visit when you are on the area. Some of the best views and scenery around

reviews.name: TravelByLisa
reviews.title: Beautiful Fall Foliage
reviews.comment: Now is the time to take the drive to Cottonwood Canyon. The leaves were beautiful and the weather was not too bad. It was very crowded the day we went. Make sure to have some good hiking shoes and you'll see some spectacular scenery.

reviews.name: Jeremy F
reviews.title: wow
reviews.comment: great hiking, just up from SLC and over from Park City. it is a wonderful wild land close by. Watch for all the flowers at their seasons and the birds that travel through--- also watch for my big buddy the moose!

reviews.name: skymouse
reviews.title: Great scenery
reviews.comment:
We drove all of the way to Brighton ski resort, great scenic ride you feel like you in the Alps.
I did not know you can go to Park City from the top of the Canyon
Park City is my favorite place to see outside of SLC, next time I will try this route to go to PC

reviews.name: Robert H
reviews.title: AWESOME!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
reviews.comment:
Not much more I can say about this awesome drive up Big Cottonwood Canyon. What a drive. I loved the scenery so much that I did it two days in a row. The trees, mountains, streams. You name it. Big Cottonwood has it. Great hiking too. Lake Blanche trail should not be missed. Continuing up the mountain you will pass by several ski resorts and continue to the small town of Brighton. There you will find a very tranquil and beautiful walk around Silver Lake. This is a real alpine lake and the scenery is splendid. Half way around the lake, there is a cut off to the twin lakes trail. Easy trail with a 700 ft incline in a 1 1/2 miles. Outstanding!
From Brighton, you can take the road up to Guardsman Pass at 11000 feet elevation. You are on top of the world at this point. The views are unparrelled.
From Guardsman Pass you drive down the mountain and take the cut off to Midway. Again another spectacular drive. Have a picnic lunch at the visitor center in Midway. After that, take the drive up to Snake Canyon...Scenery here does not get much better......Can't wait to do it again. We were very fortunate as the foliage was almost peaking throughout out drives. The reds, oranges, the contrast with the evergreens and of course the golden leaves of the aspen trees. What a sight anf lots of colorful memories.

reviews.name: operacarol
reviews.title: Gorgeous drive, great hikes
reviews.comment:
Big Cottonwood Canyon is my favorite of the canyons in the Salt Lake area. It's so scenic as you drive up, and there are lots of hiking options along the way. Some of my favorites are Donut Falls and Silver Lake( both great for all ages/fitness levels), and Lake Catherine and Twin Lakes/Lake Solitude. But that only scratches the surface.
Great fall foliage drive too!

reviews.name: Sharon C
reviews.title: Awe inspiring
reviews.comment: My favorite of the Salt Lake City canyons... I love the sheer rock walls and the views when you get up high. The hiking in this canyon is amazing. After years and years, it still makes my jaw drop as I drive up this canyon.

reviews.name: Gibsoninpa
reviews.title: Spectacular drive, well worth time and effort
reviews.comment: Beautiful views, quiet, serene nature. Not much traffic and a great escape from the hussle of the city.

reviews.name: Alicia J
reviews.title: Hiking
reviews.comment: My husband and I did the Lake Blanche trail and the Broads Fork Trail a few weekends ago. We got to the trailhead around 8am so it wouldn't be too busy. We packed plenty of snacks and water. When we got to Lake Blanche we had our brunch overlooking the lake and then continued hiking past the dam to two other lakes! It was so beautiful to see the lakes and the views going up the canyon. We weren't very tired when we got back to the parking lot so we decided to do the Broads Fork trail as well. It was much more difficult but had fewer people on it. Overall, we had a great 8 hours worth of hiking and would recommend both hikes to anyone in decent shape!

reviews.name: J. Elliott
reviews.title: Nice Drive
reviews.comment: We have an infant so we were somewhat limited in our experience. But, we drove up to the area on a Friday morning and enjoyed the nice scenery. It was the first of September and pretty cool though. So I definitely recommend a jacket even though back in SLC it was very warm! The scenery is breathtaking and it's a very nice drive!

reviews.name: Chukes17
reviews.title: Well worth hiking here
reviews.comment: We loved Big Cottonwood Canyon and did a great day hike on the Lake Blanche Trail. We packed a lunch and headed up in just over 2 hours to enjoy sandwiches by the lake. It was a gorgeous hike and the views of the mountains and canyon are amazing. There are so many trails to choose from here and it's just a short drive from SLC or Park City. Well worth the trip!

reviews.name: Ari_Skel
reviews.title: A hiker's delight
reviews.comment: This is an amazing location for all outdoorsy people. We went here in the late summer (Labor Day Weekend) and found tonnes of things to do. And I am betting that in the winter or spring/ early summer it will be even more wonderful. You have to check this area out for yourself otherwise you are definitely missing out on a great adventure. It has skiing, hiking, animal watching (birds and deers) and many more things to choose from.

reviews.name: Jim D
reviews.title: Great drive and great scenery
reviews.comment: Amazing drive and scenery just minutes from downtown SLC. I have been here in summer and winter and it is just amazing.

reviews.name: Kpop80
reviews.title: Breathtaking
reviews.comment:
Beautiful hiking areas, great for scenic drives. Absolutely breath. Taking views and atmosphere.
Truly easy to drive and navigate with a lot of stops to enjoy and take pictures. Lovely in winter with the snow capped mountains and so beautiful and full of life in spring.
Best of all worlds in march to april time of year. So picturesque and beautiful countryside to enjoy for the whole family.
Very impressed and exceeded expectations in good old slc.

reviews.name: Bavavia
reviews.title: Very pretty area
reviews.comment: I didn't get to spend much time because I did not have proper shoes, etc to really explore, I did. It have maps or anything, you should know terrain, have a trail map.. So you know where u are, easy to get lost.. Very pretty scenery, mountains.. Just a beautiful canyon.

reviews.name: Peter G
reviews.title: If you can only visit spot outside the city ...
reviews.comment: While visiting on business, it was suggested that if we wanted to see what the canyon country was like, Big Cottonwood Canyon was the place to visit. With one evening to do sightseeing, this was a great choice. The drive up the canyon was picturesque, and not at all like what I was expecting. We saw rock climbers along the way, and I was thinking my son would have loved it here. We were headed for the Silver Fork, but decided to look around before dinner while we still had daylight. The walk around Spring Lake at then end of the drive was a must-do. We had hoped to see some moose, but not today. I was surprised to realize we were over 8000 feet elevation - it didn't feel like it. And the cool, dry air was a pleasant change from the 95F in the city. After dinner, we continued up some side roads until it got dark, and headed back to our hotel. The side roads were not for the faint of heart - steep drop-offs and no guardrails! Wouldn't want to drive there when the roads were icy!

reviews.name: Ruth F
reviews.title: Silver Lake
reviews.comment: Family friendly, easy walking path around Silver Lake, in BCC. Has bathrooms, and it's free. Great spot to see wildlife (like moose) and have a picnic in the canyons. Beautiful place to get off the grid.

reviews.name: RADdoc_TX
reviews.title: Stunning views, beautiful mountains
reviews.comment: We stayed for a week in the heat of August; well, heat down in the valley anyway! It was mid 60s in the morning, up to 80 or so in the afternoon. Beautiful. Wonderful hiking trails, especially up at Silver Lake. Climbed up to Twin Lakes. Beautiful country, deer in plain view, forests,.... Warning - prepare for weather changes! It snowed and sleeted and rained on us at the top, lightning everywhere. All in all, though, it was amazing and beautiful!

reviews.name: Megapod
reviews.title: In summer, drive up and over to Park City!
reviews.comment: Stunning drive up canyon, and after you've "dead-ended" at Brighton Ski Area, drive around the loop and about 1/4 mile back down go right, and uphill (!) to cross over at about 10,000 feet via Guardsman's Pass, ending up in Park City on a spectacular drive!

reviews.name: Wendy L
reviews.title: Great drive in the canyon
reviews.comment: Big Cottonwood Canyon is breath-taking. If you get the opportunity to visit during the fall, take it. Be sure and pack a picnic.

reviews.name: TexasGingerbread
reviews.title: Beautiful drive, beautiful easy hike (more of a walk) around Silver Lake
reviews.comment:
Beautiful, perfect for small kids (age 4 were mine) and a peaceful gorgeous day! I loved it. The drive along is worth seeing. If you're wanting to escape to the mountains from SLC for the day or afternoon with small ones this is perfect!
(The next day we did the hike to Angel Falls and it was perfect for this age as well!)

reviews.name: travelholic86
reviews.title: Beautiful canyon 20 mins from downtown SLC
reviews.comment: This is a great canyon that is easily accesible if you are staying in the Salt Lake area. There are plenty of hiking trails and tons of places to rock climb. During the winter you can enjoy snowboarding and skiing at either Brighton or Solitude and of course there are plenty of places to snowshoe. Overall, the canyon is stunningly beautiful year round and provides plenty of activities.

reviews.name: TJ W
reviews.title: A day of hiking
reviews.comment: We went on several different hiking trails in the canyon. We started at donut falls which was an easy trail with beautiful stream and waterfall. Our last hike was from Brighton up to Lake Mary. This is a more challenging hike but worth the effort! Make sure to bring a sweat shirt as the temperature can drop 20 degrees in the late afternoon.

reviews.name: Jayre
reviews.title: Canyon to Brighton and Solitude Ski Resort
reviews.comment: Such a beautiful drive. Nice and cool up there during the summer. Many spots for a picnic or open fire. Easily accessible and you can continue the drive over the mountain to reach Park City (via Guardsman's Pass).

reviews.name: goanywheretogether
reviews.title: Must see
reviews.comment: Big Cottonwood Canyon was highly recommended by the locals and I can see why. This place was amazing. I had to rent a car to get there from downtown Salt Lake City, but it was worth every penny. I visited in the summer and went to snowbird and took the tram to the top <$20 and then I went hiking. Tons of great pics. The highlight of my trip.

reviews.name: cydney04106
reviews.title: great place to explore
reviews.comment: the only downside is that you can't take your dog since it's part of the watershed system. beautiful scenery.

reviews.name: Scott W
reviews.title: Worth it! Even if you only have an hour
reviews.comment:
A week ago I had a few hours with my wife and she wanted to go for a hike - So we drove to the canyon and started driving up. I took her to a favorite trail of mine and we hit the trail. Parking at the 'S' curve, we headed up the Broads Fork trail. Within minutes we were in another world. Sure we could hear the cars streaming up and down the canyon, but the aroma of pine trees and wild flowers melted the din into an unobtrusive aside.
We both loved just being out in the wild, unattached and undeterred by the electronic junk that dominates our day to day living. yes, we had no cell service - HOORAY!
45 minutes up the trail (probably 25 for the faster moving crowd) we came upon a huge rock. We paused to enjoy its unique form and then continued up a ways. We passed only 2 other people on our trek up and I pondered the proximity to more than a million people only a few miles away, and here we were in solitude.
After an hour we turned back and quickly retraced our steps. The trail was alot steeper on the way down, but we managed. Soon we arrived back at the parking lot and rested by the rushing waters of the mountain stream. We didn't want to leave and so we just basked in the overpowering sound of the rushing water.
You know we will be back

reviews.name: Cathy C
reviews.title: Beautiful
reviews.comment: This is a beautiful drive, just don't be in a hurry. At Brighton Resort take a walk around Silver Lake. We saw a moose grazing. We were in the area for a week and took the drive twice and the walk around the lake. Our grandchildren, ages 3 and 8, loved it.

reviews.name: morrishj
reviews.title: Beautiful Drive; Lots of Hikes
reviews.comment: We enjoyed our drive through Big Cottonwood Canyon, including hiking to Donut Falls and Hidden Falls. Research the hikes before you go because the signage isn't very good. Be sure to take water and a camera! We ended our drive down the canyon road by going up over Guardsman Pass. Spectacular. Where the pavement ends and it becomes more dirt/gravel, there is a place where cars were parked. Be careful... there isn't a guard rail and you could easily drive straight off the mountain!!! I wouldn't want to drive it at night!

reviews.name: Lauracello
reviews.title: Magnificent scenery and wildlife
reviews.comment: We enjoyed a beautiful summer afternoon in the canyon walking the trail around Silver Lake. Majestic peaks still had snow and the foliage was so green. We spotted several moose which were just amazing to behold.

reviews.name: CommanderChip
reviews.title: Just as I left it
reviews.comment: I learned to ski at Brighton in 1961. It hasn't changed in any appreciable fashion since then. The scenery driving up the canyon and especially at the ski resorts was as stunning as I remembered.

reviews.name: Tonto7
reviews.title: great scenery.....BUT!!!
reviews.comment:
I just spent a week in the SLC region, hiking and sightseeing. The mountain scenery, especially with late snow on the peaks, is fantastic. But be forewarned - the trail systems leave a lot to be desired, particularly in regard to signage. I have hiked in NH, ME, VT, MA, CT, NY, WY, CO, and MT, but have never seen a trail system that is totally unmarked like the trail system in the Wasatch Mountains.
Most trail heads are unmarked other than by a sign saying "Trail". A bit further on, there'll be sign saying "Stay on the trail". That is usually followed by a number of heavily trodden trails going in multiple directions, with no designation of which is the correct one. Trying to determine which is correct is impossible, since all appear to be maintained, with waterbars and stone steps. And yet., printed trail maps show only one distinct trail. If you're lucky enough to not get totally lost, you'll be rewarded with fantastic views, but will only have a vague idea of where you are. The comment of the 'locals' is "Well, you get used to it." Big canyon, small canyon, it dosen't matter, they're all the same. Good luck!

reviews.name: shake801
reviews.title: A treasure for the city
reviews.comment:
I lived back East for a decade and these canyons are a major reason I couldn't stay away any longer. Now I've lived in Salt Lake for years and still haven't explored every area of this canyon. There is always something new to challenge. Most people will just drive up and down or do a couple of short hikes or picnics. But there are literally hundreds of trails to inspire.
There is a connection with the natural world and extreme wilderness so close to a major urban center, which is a unique feature most cities don't have. Every season has options, from skiing to climbing, biking or hiking. The real canyon must be explored away from the car and road. Here is where you will encounter moose, mountain goats, and view Salt Lake City from 10,000 foot mountain peaks. That view must be earned.
If nothing else, it's always a nice day heading up the canyon relaxing.

reviews.name: Sharilyn M
reviews.title: Beautiful Mountains
reviews.comment: Skiing is great and surroundings beautiful! Even just a drive up the canyon offers breathtaking views.

reviews.name: Kim G
reviews.title: A beautiful place for a drive
reviews.comment: The canyon is in full bloom and the trees are full and green. It was a beautiful peaceful drive. It made for a nice relaxing Sunday Drive!

reviews.name: gittinsj
reviews.title: Options may be limited in early May
reviews.comment: I very recently visited Big Cottonwood Canyon in early May. There were snow flurries on the day that I visited. Some of the sites, such as Hidden Falls and the Lake Blanche Trailhead, were accessible. The Donut Falls trailhead was not open yet, so the better choice would be to go later in spring.

reviews.name: marshall5686
reviews.title: Just Go
reviews.comment: Take a day, hike, ski, take lots of pictures. This is a such a nice way to get out of the city and see what makes SLC such a great place to live for outdoor enthusiasts. The hike to do-nut falls is short and easy. You can drive over the top (Guardsman's pass) to Park City. Decide what you want to do and just go.

reviews.name: a l
reviews.title: snowshoeing
reviews.comment: great family activity. well marked trail to dougnut falls. good trail for kids. nice in the summer too. love to get out of the heat. more popular trails pretty crowded

reviews.name: Geoutah
reviews.title: Hiking but No Dogs or Bikes
reviews.comment: I love the trails of Big Cottonwood Canyon. Guardsman Pass offers the opportunity to commute between Big Cottonwood and Park City. It is truly spectacular with amazing ski resorts, fishing and rock climbing.

reviews.name: AeneasAtSea
reviews.title: Great Hiking in Summer, Great Skiing in Winter
reviews.comment:
There are a number of spectacular hikes up Big Cottonwood: the Mill B South interpretive trail is paved, so great for kids and wheelchairs; the Lake Blanche trail starts from the Miil B trailhead just before the falls, and continues for almost three miles past glacier-scarred boulders up the fork to a stunning alpine lake; across road is the Hidden Falls trail and the Mill B North Fork, which offers great overlooks. At the top of the canyon are Brighton and Alta, both great skiing destinations in winter, but in summer they are equally beautiful.
Silver Lake offers a nature center, a boardwalk, and an interpretive trail which connects up with trails to Silver lake and Lake Solitude. But the real treat is the network of trails and alpine lakes (Lake Mary, Martha and Catherine are all simply breathtaking) above the Alta parking area. Expect to see deer, moose, beautiful wildflowers, and some of the most gorgeous scenery you'll see anywhere in the world short of the Swiss Alps.

reviews.name: Sherri H
reviews.title: Beautiful
reviews.comment: God created Big Cottonwood, so we would have no doubt that He exists. Beautiful! An amazing place to take a hike, go snowboarding, skiing, camping, or just a family picnic. Another bucket list item!

reviews.name: Mark Y
reviews.title: Beautiful
reviews.comment:
Even if you don't ski, check out this canyon and its camp/picnic grounds!!
Drive up to the ski resorts for a beautiful view of the canyons and the mountains. Just as beautiful in the summer as in the winter.

reviews.name: 218SR
reviews.title: Perfect
reviews.comment:
I have driven up this canyon hundreds of times. It is beyond beautiful, in every season. It's hard to imagine a more beautiful place so close to a major city. And it comes with a huge variety of activities, great for all ages. You can fish in the lakes at the top (including Silver Lake, which is an easy walk from the parking lot), hike on trails of any level of difficulty, incomparable skiing in the winter, and many more.
To state the obvious, it does get a huge amount of snow in the winter, so be prepared. You do not want to be driving up or down the canyon in a blizzard, and oftentimes they close the road and won't let you anyway.

reviews.name: Ash R
reviews.title: Stunning. Beautiful, worthy family day trip.
reviews.comment:
Fantastic, as the title states I went with my family commonly when I lived in Utah and it's stunning. Utah is definitely a staple of natural beauty and this is a must-see if you're into that.
Beautiful scenery and a lovely way to spend an off day. Rejuvenates you by just being disconnected from the world, let alone all the calm surroundings.
However, that being said, it's very convenient to get to everywhere around it if you want to get a bite to eat at a local restaurant.

reviews.name: inHisfootsteps
reviews.title: Breathtaking
reviews.comment: I LOVE Big Cottonwood canyon! It is super convenient and easy to get to. It is also absolutely gorgeous. There is tons to do up there, great hiking trails, fishing and the best skiing around. It is also very affordable. Especially if you stay at http://www.brightonchalets.com

reviews.name: pisces025
reviews.title: Skied Solitude, great snow
reviews.comment: good grooming in a low snow year, producing great conditions in a low snow year (for Utah). The Bratwurst at the mid station restaurant was fantastic

reviews.name: Craig B
reviews.title: Go on to Park City
reviews.comment: Agreed, this most certainly is a beautiful spot to visit. Plenty of 3 season opportunities for hiking, camping, picnicking, etc. And in winter add skiing, both downhill and cross country. But if you're out for an adventurous drive when the road's been plowed, take the trip over the pass to Park City. If I lived in Utah, that, rather than I-80, would be my route between SLC and PC when the snow allows.

reviews.name: 768Jason
reviews.title: Recharge your batteries
reviews.comment: I go up this canyon year round, for skiing, looking at changing leaves in the fall (Unbelievable!) and for family pic-nics. LOVE THIS CANYON!!!

reviews.name: Zorbina
reviews.title: Beautiful place
reviews.comment: Great for skiing, hiking, having a picnic, or just for a scenic drive. Brighton and Solitude ski resorts are very nice, and Silver Fork lake is a lovely destination with a boardwalk that's wheelchair accessible during the summer months. It's a flat, easy walk around the lake, and there are trail heads for the more adventurous. The terrain is quite different from Little Cottonwood Canyon, despite being right next to it. (If I remember correctly, one was formed by a glacier, the other by a river.) It's about a 20 minute drive from downtown SLC to the mouth of the canyon, and about another 20 minutes to the top of the canyon. Silver Fork Lodge, near the top of the canyon, is a great place to stop for a meal.

reviews.name: ant100
reviews.title: Quiet
reviews.comment: Solitude... always a nice quick option from Salt Lake to avoid the hordes mobbing LCC. Cheap, quiet, pleasant.

reviews.name: Jeff D
reviews.title: Great Views
reviews.comment:
The skiing is really good in both little cottonwood canyon and big cottonwood. The drive is a bit scary however and during a big snow storm you can get stuck on either sided of the canyon.
They do a good job with the snow plowing but the drive is about 14 miles.

reviews.name: WHKRochester
reviews.title: Canyons skiing
reviews.comment: Awesome conditions early in day. Canyons is more crowded and more snowboards. Night skiing at Brighton was great!

reviews.name: ski4everbunny
reviews.title: A must see in the fall
reviews.comment: Silver Fork Lodge and restaurant is the best!!! Go for a beautiful hike around the lake and just take in the color.

reviews.name: hamptondragon
reviews.title: Always beautiful for young and old
reviews.comment:
Love Big Cottonwood Canyon. Great Hikes--some short, some long. Even just driving along the road is worth the trip, some 45-60 minutes round trip without stopping. A short walk around Silver Lake is always very nice, but there are lots of places to stop. Winter skiing is great. This place is beautiful, just can't say much more.
More crowded now than in years past, but still visit every time I come.

reviews.name: Camellia S
reviews.title: skiing is always good, but we didn't get fresh snow
reviews.comment: Air quality was really bad in Salt Lake City - something they call "inversion". Never seen it that bad before. It's something to check before deciding on a ski trip again.

reviews.name: Dustin10
reviews.title: Beautiful in the fall
reviews.comment:
if you can plan a trip when the leaves are changing, you will not be disappointed. Go up to Brighton at the top of the canyon, or continue up over Guardsman Pass (it's being paved now) to Park City. Lots of moose in that area as well, and the fall is the best time to see them.
Fantastic mountain biking up there too.

reviews.name: radmom7
reviews.title: Love this canyon
reviews.comment: This canyon goes way back to my childhood. I love the rocks, the picnic areas, the hiking areas. Very easy to get to from Salt Lake City area.

reviews.name: friendoftoodleloo
reviews.title: Good skiing but great for snowboarders
reviews.comment: Solitude and Brighton are two ski resorts up Big Cottonwood Canyon. They each have fun things about them, but I haven't been to Solitute in years. I've been to Brighton several times and at 40+ years old I am definitely in the minority. This place is very popular with the younger snowboard crowd. The number of skiers is coming back but the average age is still young.

reviews.name: Eric W
reviews.title: Awesome Experience
reviews.comment: There isn't a place quite like it. The smells and openness while under the cover of the trees is really an uplifting experience. I can only hope people don't destroy this treasure.

reviews.name: Lyn B
reviews.title: Beautiful Canyons.
reviews.comment: Expect to see a lot of people up this canyon, it has so many activities and is beautiful, but well used by the public.

reviews.name: Ron S
reviews.title: The best part of living by the mountains
reviews.comment: Whether for a hike, a picnic or to see the leaves, Big Cottonwood provides opportunities to be close to nature and enjoy the best of Salt Lake. Also enjoy a couple of nice restaurants. Brighton is a treat, winter or summer. Brighton and Solitude resorts provide lower lift prices and are preferred by the natives. No tourists in the way!

reviews.name: Danniogirl
reviews.title: Beautiful Biway
reviews.comment: Spent a good couple hours driving and stopping to take pictures of the scenery. If I had more time, a hike would have been excellent. Beautiful area of the country. Do not miss this location if you are in the area.

reviews.name: Pixtonian
reviews.title: Climbing heaven
reviews.comment: Whatever your level of expirience there is a climb for you. If you haven't climbed this is where you want to learn. I have spent much of my time in this canyon over my life and have been so greatful to live so close to so much beauty adventure and a place to just get away.

reviews.name: Micosay
reviews.title: Nature so close to a large city
reviews.comment: The canyon is 20 minutes from most parts of the city. Even in the hottest times of the year you can quickly cool off in the Alpine air and the frigid creek water. We try and visit there every summer. And of course the canyon houses much skiing. It is always hard to come back down into the valley after the beauty and coolness.

reviews.name: GButler
reviews.title: Definitely worth a drive up there. Stunning views
reviews.comment: Well worth a drive and stop for a little stroll. Scenery is beautiful! But be prepared with clothing as weather changes quickly !

reviews.name: Wayne H
reviews.title: STOP SKI LINK!!
reviews.comment: This is a great canyon. Don't change it. STOP SKI LINK! Ski Link is an attempt to steal Public Forrest Land and sell it to Talisker Company in order to place a gondola from the Canyons to Solitude through pristine forest land. This is no more than a land grab by the super wealthy. STOP SKI LINK!!

reviews.name: hrdirsteins
reviews.title: Beautiful Views
reviews.comment: Big Cottonwood Canyon is a beautiful canyon to drive up. The Brighton Ski area is at the top and the landscape is incredible. Drive up to the top of the pass to go to Deer Valley and experience incredible views.

reviews.name: JanO56
reviews.title: Photographer's Dream
reviews.comment: The scenery was stunning driving up. Fir trees, autumn leaves and babbling brooks. We dined at the Silver Fork. A quaint little spot.

reviews.name: wine2love2
reviews.title: Worth the time for a drive all the way
reviews.comment:
Big Cottonwood Canyon is different from Little Cottonwood in that it huge taller boulders and more rocky and more narrow roads. They are both beautiful. It doesn't take that long to get to Brighton.
I saw many cyclists and hikers. I am not a hiker but still enjoyed the views. There are several easy walks/hikes. Silver Lake was beautiful. Many places to pull over for picnics. Drive all the way to the end to Brighton ski resort. (I saw a moose wandering around!)

reviews.name: TacomaGuys
reviews.title: great drive to Park City
reviews.comment: Cottonwood Canyon (just southeast of SLC) is a very scenic drive up to the Brighton ski area. From there you can head up over Guardsman Pass (over 9000 feet in elevation) on to Park City. Gorgeous views of canyon walls and mountains with fall foliage coming into its own. View from the top is spectacular. Just don't be afraid of heights!

reviews.name: LGC
reviews.title: Gorgeous drive
reviews.comment: Big cottonwood is awesome - tons of hiking trails, skiing at brighton or solitude, or silver lake up at Brighton is perfect for a casual stroll. Would definitely recommend.

reviews.name: nuyu_12
reviews.title: Impressive!
reviews.comment: Very cool drive through some impressive rock. GPS may throw you off so just follow Big Cottonwood Canyon road and it will lead you straight in.

reviews.name: Benita C
reviews.title: Rough hike
reviews.comment: I went on a 3 hour hike and it was rough but well worth it. The hiking trails are very rocky and steep but its a good work out. Once I made it to the top of the mountain I felt victory, LOL! While driving to the park you see the beauty the Utah has to offer. I enjoyed it, you will too.

reviews.name: naivevictimPhnomPenh
reviews.title: See it all on a drive up Big Cottonwood Canyon!
reviews.comment: See the twisted rock formations that show how powerful forces turned stone to putty in nature's hand. See the majestic mountains towering above, and if you can visit in the fall, see the most beautiful colorful display of autum leaves anywhere on the planet. In the winter you can ski at any one of several world-class resorts, in the fall you can listen to the Utah Symphany play the 1812 overature with real mountain men firing real cannons during the finally, (or is that Little Cottonwood Canyon?). If you keep going you can visit Robert Redford's Sundace resort, and if your timing is right take in the Sundance film festival. What a bargain!

reviews.name: FineTimer
reviews.title: Nature at it's best!
reviews.comment: Make sure to check out the sides of the canyon walls for remnants of the gold ining days. Look for aquaducts built right into the sides of the mountains!

reviews.name: Frank A
reviews.title: Beautiful canyon.
reviews.comment: The scenery is wonderful, but the road is a bit winding and not the widest. It would be ok for a small RV, but the bigger and longer rigs will cause the people on the road behind you to cuss at you a bit. There are turn-outs, etc. Lots of picnic areas and some camping spots. The ski resorts have year-round activities. And it's 10-20 degrees cooler than in the valley.

reviews.name: Scott W
reviews.title: Alpine get away!
reviews.comment: I love the canyons. I love how close they are to my home. I love how I can drive up them, park and within a few short hours of hiking I am alone and solitary. Amazing! just one tip, go during the week. go early and just be nice if you see others around.

reviews.name: MR137
reviews.title: Big?
reviews.comment: I've been to Big Cottonwood Canyon and to Little Cottonwood Canyon and it always seems to me that Little Cottonwood Canyon is bigger than Big Cottonwood Canyon.

reviews.name: craetz
reviews.title: Beautiful Drive anytime of year.
reviews.comment: This Canyon is beautiful. Fun to see the trees green up in the spring. In the summer, it is great for a hike, bbq or just for a drive. The fall is the best with the foliage. Then the winter with a blanket of snow is yet another beautiful experience. All leads to the ski resorts and what is offered there.

reviews.name: Brad L
reviews.title: My favorite drive through a mountain canyon
reviews.comment: Amazing tall mountains with huge rock walls made of interesting formations. Whole drive is accompanied by a raging river. At the top one can cross Guardsman's Pass and continue on to Park City. Doesn't get any better than this

reviews.name: Taste Fairy
reviews.title: A Great Escape!
reviews.comment:
If you are in Salt Lake City, you don't have to travel very far to experience the peace and beauty of nature. There are so many places to explore, but Big Cottonwood Canyon is one of the best places to start. My favorite place to go is Silver Lake. It's a great place to take a walk, or enjoy a picnic lunch. If you are feeling more adventurous, there are also several lakes you can hike to from there. (Hope you remembered to bring your camera or phone to take pictures!)
For hiking ideas, there is a place you can get information at the start of the Silver Lake trail. There are also restrooms there.
The trails to Twin Lake and Lake Solitude start on the North side of Silver Lake. From the fork, you can go left to Twin Lake or Right to Lake Solitude.
Twin Lake: My favorite part of the trail to Twin Lake is the section that cuts through an aspen forest. After that the trail gets pretty rocky and I didn't enjoy that as much in the hot sun. Not the best trail to hike mid-day! When I arrived at Twin Lake (Reservoir) I was a little disappointed with the view and not sure if I would care to hike this trail again. My sister and I decided to take a "short cut" down the road on the way back and I don't recommend doing that. It was faster, yes, but too steep for me. I'd rather go back the way I came next time even if it's longer. Too hard on my knees. Guess I'm a wimp. :)
Lake Solitude: This was my favorite trail to hike. Beautiful aspens, lots of wildflowers, deer...and possibly other wildlife. This trail felt very isolated to me, I wouldn't feel very comfortable hiking this one alone, but I could do this trail again and again. The lake at the end of the trail looked like a moose pond. It wasn't big, but it was pretty. Definitely a place of "solitude."
___________
Dog Lake/Lake Mary: This trail starts out at Brighton Ski Resort. The beginning of the trail is pretty steep, it begins right up the hill near the ski lift. The trail is easy to follow from there. (Restrooms back at Silver Lake) It was a nice trail that just seems to keep going up, up, up. Bring water...and a picnic lunch while you're at it. Dog Lake was a nice, easy, short walk to a very pretty and isolated moose pond. (No moose when I was there) Worth the short walk to see it, for sure! The trail to Lake Mary is also worth the hike. I wasn't disappointed once the picturesque lake (reservoir) came into view. I was glad I brought my camera! There were several families up there enjoying a picnic and I was wishing I was more prepared...maybe next time.

reviews.name: JBells16
reviews.title: Beautiful
reviews.comment: The canyons is such an amazing sight to behold. I highly recommend that everyone visiting Utah make it up to the Canyons. Truly breath taking!

reviews.name: shaolynn
reviews.title: Lovely campgrounds, great drive
reviews.comment: We were there for a wedding and reception and so enjoyed the site (sites 1 and 9). Beautiful meadow for the wedding and a charming open-faced log cabin thingy for the reception. High alpine beauty in early August complete with ground squirrels. A wonderful day's getaway from the city.

reviews.name: Ann R
reviews.title: Great hike
reviews.comment: Many hiking trails - you choose the difficulty. Great scenery and also saw moose - close up! The mountain flowers were an added bonus. This area is beautiful during any season and is quite easy to get to.

reviews.name: Mary C
reviews.title: The most beautiful place!
reviews.comment: I cant get enough of this canyon. Enormouse mountains covered with pine trees throughout. I love twin peaks hiking trail, Spruces camping ground and so many other attractions. If you are in Utah, you should definitely visist this place.

reviews.name: NikkiZyp
reviews.title: Beautiful Canyon
reviews.comment: Lots of great hikes, good views from the road for drivers, rock climbing, biking, trail running are all possible in this canyon. Some of the best hikes are in the upper part of the canyon.

reviews.name: Linda B
reviews.title: Lovely!
reviews.comment: We were lucky to be able to over the pass to Park City. The drive has amazing views but it's a bit scary in a rentacar. No guardrails and big drops. My husband was white knuckled driving on it. We'd drive it again though because it was so lovely!

reviews.name: Cecee B
reviews.title: Really Awesome
reviews.comment: You have to see this place if you are close by. Well worth the drive. The views are simply stunning. The weather is great in the summer time!

reviews.name: TahoeMark
reviews.title: A must-see place!
reviews.comment: Well worth the short drive from SLC! In the summer the valley and surrounding mountains are gorgeous. In the winter, snow is the dominate theme (have the proper car and tires)

reviews.name: kwhatley
reviews.title: Beautiful canyon - road is very "New England-esque"
reviews.comment:
Wonderful views of the mountains once you get above the tree line.
Drive in the tree line area reminds me of driving in the New England mountains.
Utah has beautiful mountains and you'll get great views at the top!

reviews.name: Adam L
reviews.title: Beat the heat
reviews.comment: A great place to go to get out of the heat. Tons of recreation options, particularly hiking and climbing. Head to the top of the canyon to see Solitude and Brighton ski resorts.

reviews.name: Ryan R
reviews.title: Beautiful canyon!
reviews.comment: Great place to explore hiking and camping in the summer. Also, fantastic skiing in the winter. You will not regret going!

reviews.name: DebbieRB
reviews.title: Beautiful canyon to explore
reviews.comment: So many things to do and see up this canyon. Be prepared to stay a while. There are hikes for all ages and abilities. A great hike for children and the elderly is up close to Brighton Ski resort. Its called Silver Lake. It makes a nice big, pretty much level, loop around this small lake. If you want to extend this hike you can go to Lake Solitude for a wonderful view. It is more of an up hill hike but so worth it. You will often see moose up this canyon and deer. In August the wildflowers up in the Albion Basin area are spectacular. The hike to Donut Falls, about 1/2 way up the canyon is also a nice one. There are several great camp grounds up this canyon. The Spruces and Redmonds are 2 of my favorites.

reviews.name: Adam P
reviews.title: Beautiful canyon with lot's of stuff to do
reviews.comment: In the winter, Big Cottonwood has two ski resorts, both allow skiers and snowboarders and are fairly cheap and family oriented. In the summer, you can mountain bike, hike, go to a restaurant or two, visit some beautiful waterfalls....the list goes on and on. I'm pretty sure there's only certain spots that you can camp in, though.

reviews.name: lisafels
reviews.title: Excellent hiking and great sledding spots
reviews.comment: We love the hiking trails in Big Cottonwood Canyon, and the Storm Mountain day use area where we often have campfire picnics at night. There is a nice sledding hill near donut falls.

reviews.name: Bob836
reviews.title: Donut Falls Hike - Perfect for the Family
reviews.comment: About nine miles up from the mouth of Big Cottonwood Canyon is the turn off that leads to Donut Falls. (See the website listed with this review.) We took seven young children ages 11 months to ten years. All made it safely. The trail is relatively smooth and well groomed until the very end. You can stop at the base of the falls or continue on the rocks to get closer to the falls. The scenery is beautiful and the length is perfect for young hikers . . . It's less than a mile each way. There is a pit toilet at the trail head and limited parking nearby (about 20 spaces). We wend on a summer weekday, but apparently you can go year round, if you like to snowshoe in the winter.

reviews.name: lchdbw
reviews.title: Snowboarding heaven
reviews.comment: Big Cottonwood has the ski resorts Brighton and Solitude. One of my favorites is Brighton, for more of a casual, "mom & pop" feel. The snow on this side of the mountains is more reliable than the Park City area, and you have 2 great options. Solitude is more sophisticated, with a village and condos, but still has more of a personal feel, not so large and commercial.

reviews.name: PeterBallant
reviews.title: Gorgeous
reviews.comment: This canyon has it all. Great restaurants, hikes and wonderful views.

reviews.name: giggatygiggaty
reviews.title: Big Cottonwood, Little Cottonwood; whatever it takes!
reviews.comment: Beautiful, remote, tranquil, and just minutes from downtown Salt Lake City!

reviews.name: skithebird
reviews.title: Not too crowded
reviews.comment: Its beautiful here and its not too crowded for being so close to the city. I would recommend this for visitors.

reviews.name: berniet
reviews.title: A treasure in SLC
reviews.comment: Hike, fish, picnic, bike, ski, snow shoe, etc, etc, etc in some of the most spectacular scenery in the US. All within 20 minutes of down town SLC. If you enjoy the outdoors there are few places where you can enjoy such variety of activity and scenery anywhere. If you have the opportunity, Mon - Thurs are less crowded but if you don't mind hiking a bit you can always find solitude. Take the road up to Guardsman's Pass and over to Deer Valley Park City for a relaxed trip to the other side of the Wasatch.

reviews.name: Terry B
reviews.title: Beautiful Canyon Minutes from Downtown
reviews.comment:
We love Big Cottonwood Canyon, winter, spring, summer and fall. Enjoy the greatest snow on earth at Solitude and Brighton ski resorts. Cross country, downhill, snow boarding ... it is a winter wonderland. Snow usually lingers well into spring and sometimes into summer at the higher elevations. We've camped in snow in June and experienced snowfall in August.
My favorite time of the year in Big Cottonwood is summer. It's a great place to escape the summer heat for a picnic, a hike or a weekend campout. There are several picnic areas and trailheads just off the road. Three camp areas are usually very busy all summer. We have an annual family reunion at Jordan Pines (group sites only). Spruces and Redman campgrounds have single and group camp sites.
Storm Mountain is very popular for picnics, hiking and rock climbing. Donut Falls and Silver Lake are popular destinations. Other hikes take the adventurous higher and deeper into the mountains. The canyon road is popular with bicyclists. The creek provides some fun fishing.
Big Cottonwood Canyon is certainly a treasure in the Wasatch Mountains!

reviews.name: tdw295
reviews.title: Great scenic drive
reviews.comment: If you are looking to spend a couple of hours site seeing, this the place to go.

reviews.name: Oak Druid
reviews.title: Beautiful and well traveled.
reviews.comment: We hiked Mill B North trail. It was pretty easy going, but takes a while to the top. Met some really nice folks on the trail, all very friendly. Lots of climbers.

reviews.name: Saxeygirl
reviews.title: A locally loved and heavily used canyon.
reviews.comment: This is a beautiful canyon located to the east of Salt Lake. There are picnic areas, hiking trails, campgrounds, a girls' summer camp, and several ski resorts.

reviews.name: 945945JT
reviews.title: Scenic Drive - Nice break from it all
reviews.comment: It's a little fun to get to but once you get to 'the edge of humanity', you will be welcomed with some pretty beautiful scenery. Go slow, take every opportunity to capture the brook and its little sections of chop. Really nice.

reviews.name: Tom B
reviews.title: Great!!
reviews.comment: Went skiing with family. Wonderful place and great atmosphere. Many resorts up there and all are better than the other.. Wonder place wish snow was more but that's weather for you !

reviews.name: Nick C
reviews.title: Trails, views, wildlife, streams, rocks, skiing, mountains, etc.
reviews.comment: It has everything. I love to travel up Big or Little Cottonwood and take care of all nature has to offer!

reviews.name: Mark H
reviews.title: awesome bike ride
reviews.comment: Great scenery all the way up the canyon. Strong (updraft) wind on the descent really slows things down. Good hiking at Brighton when the snow clears.

reviews.name: Jeff H
reviews.title: A beautiful drive in the mountains close by
reviews.comment: I love to go up Big Cottonwood Cyn. It's really close to our home in Sandy and reaffirms why I live in Salt Lake County. The canyon is especially glorious in the fall as the leaves change colors. It's a must see.

reviews.name: Sherry B
reviews.title: Enjoying the canyon
reviews.comment: Our son drove us up the canyon to go snowshoeing & to see Brighton Ski area, where he snowboards. Beautiful area. Enjoyed snowshoeing around Silver Lake area. Later had a picnic at one of the picnic areas along the road.

reviews.name: adventureguy_58
reviews.title: Unbeatable Outdoor Recreation
reviews.comment: Great scenery year round. Tremendous skiing in uncrowded conditions usually catering to knowledgeable outsiders and locals. Two ski resorts which are particularly family friendly. Our children learned to ski at Brighton and they loved the variety of skiing from beginner to double black diamond runs. Solitude is also a great ski area right next door for variety and a beautiful ski village. There doesn't ever seem to be a wait for lifts at either place.Hiking in season is terrific. The hike to Mary's Lake is fun and scenic. Trails are fun for all age groups. Snowshoeing and cross country skiing and snowmobiling in addition to skiing in winter. A plus and a minus at same time is the limited visitor accommodations but easily accessible to downtown SLC. Also, we take the bus from DT SLC and that is relaxing and you meet nice people.

reviews.name: Genevieve G
reviews.title: Personal drive up to Snowbird
reviews.comment: Also my husband went fishing up there, and we took some friends to walk about a lake, and I found the Young Women's getaway I went to as a young girl.

reviews.name: Glabrezu
reviews.title: I Love Riding Through This Area
reviews.comment: It's so pretty, no matter the season. I suppose that's all I have to say. =)

reviews.name: DebPlaz
reviews.title: Snow, Ski, Food
reviews.comment: Great snow, great skiing, Rustler has great brunch.

reviews.name: Mouserina
reviews.title: Nice, but crowded.
reviews.comment: If planning a camping trip on any weekend in the warm months, make sure to book a reservation well in advanced. Fantastic camping and very close to the valley.

reviews.name: bakaroma
reviews.title: everyone all the tme
reviews.comment: No matter the time of year there is something for everyone in this canyon. Your fitness level nor your general disposition can keep you from appreciating this place.

reviews.name: Rocketleech
reviews.title: Park City is great!
reviews.comment: Spent a week in PC, lots of snow, not a lot of people, no waiting for lifts. Canyons and Deer Valley were also outstanding. 1 hour from SLC airport to the slopes, easy drive in almost any weather. Weather was very mild, more like spring skiing, but snow held up pretty well. Plan to do it again next year.

reviews.name: Sttflygirl
reviews.title: Skiing is Awesome
reviews.comment: We love skiing in Utah. Our favorite is Alta, but Solitude and Brighton deserve a mention. Brighton great for beginners but too many snowboarders. They ate not allowed on Alta which is why we go there. Utah ski resorts always have a substantial base .

reviews.name: Judith A
reviews.title: Groomed trails
reviews.comment: We skied at Solitude and Brighton, both located in Big Cottonwood Canyon. The snow and groomed trails were great.

reviews.name: aspd3815900
reviews.title: Don't go here !!!!!!
reviews.comment: Look! For many years Utah was the best kept secret in America. Too many people are finding out that in just minutes you can be from the valley into the most beautiful mountain scenery you can imagine. If you do visit don't tell anyone. We kinda like to keep it to ourselves. Plenty of camping / picnic areas available but sometimes you have to plan well to get one now that the secret is out.

reviews.name: TheSaent
reviews.title: Gorgeous outdoors, all skill level
reviews.comment:
This canyon is gorgeous. The hikes are incredible, and there is good fishing to be had along the way.
All skill levels will find something here, even if it's just a Sunday drive.

reviews.name: Wimskee
reviews.title: In My Backyard
reviews.comment: If you are looking for an incredible mountain experience, look no further than Big Cottonwood canyon. No matter the season, there are so many things to do. Hiking, biking, skiing, photography, rock climbing, picnicking, and so much more. It's easily accessible and worth the trip.

reviews.name: SaltLakeProger
reviews.title: Love the canyon and the fishing!
reviews.comment: There is a lot of traffic, but the canyon is awesome! Great restaurants and I've caught Brook, Brown, Cutthroat and Rainbow Trout in the creek!

reviews.name: jenjakeusa
reviews.title: Beautiful canyon with awesome skiing and hiking!
reviews.comment: LCC offers great skiing/boarding at both Solitude and Brighton. Summer months offer great trails for hiking at any leve of expertise.

reviews.name: Glenn C
reviews.title: Always a pleasure.
reviews.comment: The geologic features are incredible. The fall colors are breathtaking. Hiking around the lakes is always relaxing and photographic.

reviews.name: neh11
reviews.title: Pretty
reviews.comment: This canyon is very pretty. There are many great hikes you can go on. It is a wonderful place to visit.

reviews.name: Sonoran_Skies
reviews.title: Brighton and Solitude are here
reviews.comment: No good snow for the start of the 2011-2012 season. Brighton tried hard though and my kids liked it the best of the e we visited.

reviews.name: Mary V
reviews.title: The drive is worth taking.
reviews.comment: Even if you don't ski you can enjoy the scenic drive to the top. Winter or summer, Big Cottonwood Canyon is as beautiful as any place in the world.

reviews.name: LoveToTravelToo04
reviews.title: Fall Color at its Best
reviews.comment: Big Cottonwood Canyon has every bright fall color imaginable. There are beautiful sheer granite cliffs adjacent to thinkly forested mountains filled with bright color. The colors seem much more vivid and bright than the usual folliage.

reviews.name: Golfer4status
reviews.title: Surround yourself in natural beauty
reviews.comment:
This canyon offers magnificent rock cliffs, waterfalls, hiking trails, ski lifts at the top, beautiful flowers in the spring through the fall, wildlife sightings, and fresh air.
Fee for skiing or riding chairlifts. There is no fee to hike.
Bathrooms, food facilities are found at the lodges, if they are open.

reviews.name: WeveSeenItAll
reviews.title: Our Favorite
reviews.comment: We love the spruces. It's nice that the canyon is so accessible and easy to enjoy the wilderness just 15 minutes from the city.

reviews.name: constanttraveler71
reviews.title: LOVELY CANYON; COME PREPARED
reviews.comment: Nice for families. Take along food, chairs and other gear. Cottonwood is becoming a victim of its popularity. choose days and hours to avoid the crowds.

reviews.name: John_Gaudy
reviews.title: Summer or Winter Beauty
reviews.comment:
Whether summer or winter, there is always something fun to do or beautiful to see. Good entry level hike at Donut Falls.
Or try one of the ski resorts. Can't fail there and the slopes suit all levels of difficulty

reviews.name: UTSW
reviews.title: Quintessential Utah Canyon
reviews.comment: Great canyon for so many things...15 minutes from downtown and a totally different world. Take a drive to see Fall colors or an amazing vista of valleys and peaks at the top of the canyon (great year round but can get slushy and sketchy for people not accustomed to driving narrow canyons with steep drop-offs and snow), skiing or brunch/lunch at the resorts, an easy hike around Silver Lake (part has boardwalk, the rest is a dirt path, walkable in flip flops or hiking shoes), or sight wildlife (we've seen a golden eagle swoop down to scoop up road kill about 20 feet away, 2 bald eagles, moose, etc.). The drive is also spectacular, winding along next to a river filled with little trout, steep cliffs rising straight up at certain points. Some summer weekend afternoons we escape the city heat and take a quick picnic up and sit by the river.

reviews.name: JPaulBerg
reviews.title: Favorite place to Ski
reviews.comment: Brighton is great, but I love Solitude. Nuff said.

reviews.name: Jack B
reviews.title: great variety of outdoor options
reviews.comment: Big Cottonwood has a lot of hiking options. With young kids, we love the Silver Lake walk at the base of Brighton ski resort. We have seen moose in the shallows here about a third of the time, munching away on the water plants. The rangers come out and keep you at a safe distance. There are dozens of trails for hikes into waterfalls, with widely varying levels of difficulty. Donut Falls is popular and can be crowded in summer. There are many internet sites that describe the various trails, and it is worth doing some research in advance. The Silver Fork Restaurant is about half way up the canyon. Its deck is very popular for summer weekend brunches and as an after ski place in the winter. The Porcupine Grill at the base of the Canyon in SLC is another after ski hot spot for beer, pizza, and pub food.

reviews.name: SLCparrothead
reviews.title: A nice canyon.
reviews.comment: This is a typical example of a mountain canyon out west. Lots of places to hike in the summertime. Great wildflowers and foliage in the fall. In the winter, there are great places to ski and abundant snowfall.

reviews.name: JMagicfan
reviews.title: Great Scenic Drive
reviews.comment: This was a beatiful drive with great scenery. The mountains were straight up in spots and checking out the ski resorts was cool. The snow had not quite filled things in when we were there.

reviews.name: Osdanuwati
reviews.title: hiking and skiing and beautiful vistas
reviews.comment: Brighton and Solitude for skiing and hiking and numerous trails - both easy and hard to find for wildflowers, waterfalls, lakes, creek viewing and fall colors. Great place to play right next to the Salt Lake Valley.

reviews.name: Greg M
reviews.title: Best canyon for adventure in SLC
reviews.comment: You can find a little of everything in this canyon. I am a local here in SLC. In the winter: Skiing & Snowboarding, Snowshoeing, Sledding, x-country/ Back country Skiing. Summer: Hiking, Rock climbing, Biking, Fishing, camping Etc...I can't even begin to mention all the trails or adventures I have experienced up that canyon. A popular hike in both Winter and Summer is doughnut falls. I go up there mostly to Rock Climb because it is a good place with a variety of difficulties. Meet your friends at the park and ride and carpool up to your venue. This canyon is one just like those "Choose Your Own Adventure" books. Choose what sport you will play next!

reviews.name: Tracey M
reviews.title: Welcoming Wendover Will!!!
reviews.comment: What a welcoming sign to Wendover. Wendover Will is lit up with bright neon and waving hello to all who enter town. This is a historic marker and a blast from the past. It is nice to see a little bit of old school

reviews.name: R M
reviews.title: A Rich Historical Marker
reviews.comment:
Wendover Will has been a staple of Wendover and its communities ever since I can remember, even as a kid in the 80s. I am super stoked that West Wendover city has re-lighted the ol' bloke! The only drawback is there isnt any parking that I would consider "safe".
I was delighted to stop and read the plaques with the rich history behind Wendover Will and its creator-namesake. Kudos, West Wendover!

reviews.name: Wanda H
reviews.title: First of all, it's FREE...
reviews.comment: At the edge of the parking area were quite a few plaques on pedestals with LOTS of historical information on them! Also, extremely scenic area.

reviews.name: Don and Lynn I
reviews.title: Hello and goodbye, Will!
reviews.comment: Great welcome sign. There was a deer grazing at the base of the statue, too. Although we liked Will, the gaming there was pitiful. (Will should have a sign: Empty yer pockets, here, pardner!)

reviews.name: Susan L
reviews.title: Big as life!
reviews.comment: I remember him at the edge of town by a casino, drawing in tourists with his light up neon. Someone spent about $200,000 spent to restore and move him down the boulevard. Fun to see especially for nostalgic reasons or kids.

reviews.name: Guy
reviews.title: Wendover Will
reviews.comment: Took a long walk to the west side of town and checked out Wendover Will. Took a few pictures. It's cool that they kept the big neon sign. Beautiful view from there.

reviews.name: Paulflagler
reviews.title: He's standing in the middle of the road blocking traffic.
reviews.comment: Not sure when he was built, or made but I understand it one time he used to wave at people coming into town.

reviews.name: jdmrestor
reviews.title: Wendover Icon !
reviews.comment: Wendover Will, or referred to as Bendover Bill by the gamblers is a must stop and see. Interesting, at the base of the sign are bricks inscribed with the names and dates of many of the racers that were on the Bonneville Salt Flats. Another place to see is the Enola Gay hangar at the airport. A lot of history in Wendover

reviews.name: MichaelsLost
reviews.title: West end of town
reviews.comment: It is located on the west end of town on the main street through Wendover. It has been there for years, and is kind of cool to look at, take a picture and not much else.

reviews.name: John M
reviews.title: Blast from the past. I had to take his photo!
reviews.comment: Big signs from another era are such a blast from the past, that I had to stop I and take his photo! Las Vegas has a museum dedicated to old signs like this.

reviews.name: Doug and Linda W
reviews.title: Attraction
reviews.comment: Lots of parking, accessible via the parking area. Great place for pictures and they encourage selfies and actually give you information as to where to send them. Areal piece of history.

reviews.name: Debra G
reviews.title: Very interesting story connected with this. Very Coool and was fun to see.,
reviews.comment: Very interesting story connected with this. Very Coool and was fun to see. Way at the end of the strip

reviews.name: Skwiki
reviews.title: Great place to get out of the car and walk around
reviews.comment:
This is a cool, old remnant that demonstrates how interesting it must have been to travel back in the 50's and earlier. Beautiful neon welcoming you into this border town.
Wendover is usually a gas and snack stop for us, but we always make sure we at least drive by Will. There is a grassy area to the west and a few plaques. The only issue is I'm not sure where you can legally stop to get a few photos. The road isn't busy but it didn't look like there is an approved area.

reviews.name: 341freddyb
reviews.title: a truly historic icon marker and traveller stop for photo

The memories rooted into my mind of the many times my parents took us as kids on drives are truly PRICELESS in our De Soto sedan and yes, stopping by what was then THE STATELINE casino for a lunch. A treat indeed for us and for you? A travel back in time through a picture.. Enjoy :)

reviews.name: backpacker31
reviews.title: A Piece of Americana
reviews.comment: Iconic statue welcoming visitors to this remote outpost. Unfortunately, upon my arrival it was extremely windy - limiting my visit. There’s some interesting history behind Wendover Will. Cute if you’re into classic Americana. A visit to the adjacent Victory Highway is recommended.

reviews.name: Excursion760043
reviews.title: Birthday Celebration!

reviews.title: JE Utah

Either way, Will is a must see. The din of I 80 traffic passing by. The winds of the high desert, and the lights of the casinos shimmering just a few blocks away.

reviews.name: Timothy R
reviews.title: you may use the shuttle
reviews.comment:
On West Wendover Blvd. there is hardly any traffic.Easy to get around any time day or night. not to many stop lights. You might want to use the shuttle also,24 hours a day.
.
